content:
I apologize for the confusion in my earlier responses. I made a mistake in my earlier response when I stated that William of Tyre's account does not mention the ransom demand.

In fact, William of Tyre does mention the ransom demand in his account of the incident involving Reynald de Chatillon and the Patriarch of Antioch. According to William of Tyre, Reynald took the Patriarch captive and demanded a large ransom for his release. The Patriarch was eventually ransomed at a high price, after which he was released.

I apologize for any confusion or misinformation I may have caused, and I hope this more accurate information is helpful.
